block.p: Deadly Form of Hepatitis Hits Troubled Iraqi Areas A form of hepatitis that is especially lethal for pregnant women has broken out in two of Iraq's most troubled districts, Iraqi Health Ministry officials said. They said a collapse of water and sewage systems is probably at the root of the outbreak.

A rocket attack aimed at an American convoy in Baghdad killed 4 Iraqis and wounded 14 others, according to the American military and Iraqi security forces. Meanwhile, kidnappings of foreigners continued, with a total of eight employees of an Egyptian cellphone company abducted since Wednesday, officials and a company employee said.
Three more members of the Navy Seals have been charged with abusing Iraqi detainees, two of whom died in American custody in Iraq after they were beaten, officials said.

U.N. Aide Offers Plan for Darfur The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees suggested that limited autonomy for the Darfur region of Sudan could quell the rebellion there, but made it clear that debating self-rule was not an option.

I.A.E.A. Seeks Access in Brazil The International Atomic Energy Agency is trying to reach an agreement with Brazil that would guarantee its inspectors unimpeded access to a planned uranium-enrichment plant. Brazil is hoping to begin operating the plant this year.
Violence Darkens Yom Kippur A Palestinian mortar round struck a home in a Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip and killed an Israeli-American woman, as Israelis prepared to mark Yom Kippur.
NASA to Send Crew to Station A new crew will be sent to the International Space Station next month even though there are concerns about maintaining adequate oxygen and other supplies on the craft.

House Leaders Propose Less Power for Spy Post House Republican leaders introduced a long-awaited bill that would grant more limited powers to a new national intelligence director than those recommended by the Sept. 11 commission or called for in a companion bill in the Senate.

Bush and Kerry Focus on Iraq Senator John Kerry declared that President Bush had repeatedly ''made the wrong choices in the war on terror,'' becoming so distracted by Iraq that the struggle against Al Qaeda suffered.
The president hit back hard at Mr. Kerry for what he called attacks on the credibility of Prime Minister Ayad Allawi of Iraq.
4th Hurricane Threatens Coast Hundreds of thousands of people on Florida's east coast were told to leave their homes as Hurricane Jeanne approached.

Floodwaters receded in Gona√Øves, Haiti, where then-Tropical Storm Jeanne took more than 1,000 lives, as tired and hungry survivors labored to clear the mud and debris from what was left of their homes.
Three back-to-back hurricanes in Florida have crippled the campaign season there, and candidates are starting to make up for lost time.
Battle Over Hendrix Estate A Seattle judge removed Jimi Hendrix's stepsister, Janie, 43, and her cousin as trustees of his estate and denied a brother, Leon, 56, any inheritance.
Wealthy Patrons of Politics Wealthy contributors have emerged as a pre-eminent force in campaigns this year despite attempts to curb the influence of big money by rewriting campaign finance law.

Officer Fatally Shoots A Suspect in Queens A police sergeant shot and killed a paroled felon in the driveway of a suburban Queens home after the suspect battered a lieutenant and took his gun, the police said. The gun discharged during the struggle and the sergeant believed that the lieutenant had been shot, the police said.

Day Care Official Fired The New York City health commissioner fired the official in charge of child-care inspections after learning that two inspectors had visited a day care center an hour before a 7-month-old baby was found there unconscious and possibly already dead.
3 Not Guilty Pleas in Hartford Three men indicted on charges of using the office of former Gov. John G. Rowland as a racketeering enterprise pleaded not guilty.
7 Cyclists Arrested at Protest Seven people were arrested and 40 bicycles were seized as about a thousand cyclists rode in Manhattan to protest automobile pollution.

Accusation of Plagiarism A psychiatrist and a writer for The New Yorker accused the English playwright Bryony Lavery, left, of using parts from their work in her Tony award-nominated drama ''Frozen.''
California Gets Tougher California regulators approved a plan aimed at drastically reducing vehicle emissions over the next 11 years of gases scientists have linked to global warming.
AT&T Shedding Jobs AT&T, after promising to retreat from the residential phone market, has started to dismantle its operations by closing telemarketing and customer service call centers.
Airline Tries to Raise Cash US Airways asked a bankruptcy judge to approve emergency pay cuts of 23 percent and other moves in order to raise cash.
Stocks Down for the Week The Dow rose 8.34 points, to 10,047.24, 237.22 points below last week's close. The Nasdaq fell 6.95 points, to 1,879.48, 30.61 points below last week.
Editorials: An un-American way to campaign; the persecuted, in chains; Carol E. Lee on a family's saying an unexpected goodbye to a reluctant soldier.
Columns: David Brooks, Nicholas D. Kristof.
